questions.text: A 2 year- the male child was brought to OPD by his parents with complaints of the absence of testis in the right scrotum. On examination, the scrotum right scrotum is underdeveloped; the testis is not palpable. About testicular descent, which of the following statements is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Testis lies at the internal inguinal ring at two months of gestation

options.label: B
options.text: Descend to scrotum occurs between 7 and 9 months

options.label: C
options.text: Mechanism of descent is poorly understood but probably involves Mullerian inhibiting substance

options.label: D
options.text: Maternal chorionic gonadotrophin stimulates the growth of the testis and may facilitate its migration

questions.correct_answer: A. Testis lies at the internal inguinal ring at two months of gestation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Testis lies at the internal inguinal ring at two months of gestation Testis lie at the internal inguinal ring at three months of gestation.

Highyeild:

Undescended testis Sketchy descent of the testis, also known as cryptorchidism, occurs when one or both testes are arrested at some point in the typical path to the scrotum. Incidence: About 3% of full-term and 30% of premature male infants are born with one or both testes undescended Pathology : (Sites of arrest) Intraabdominal Within the inguinal canal Extracanalicular Ectopic Testes that are absent from the scrotum after three months of age are unlikely to descend Histological changes in the testis can be seen from 1 year of age An incompletely descended testis tends to atrophy as puberty approaches Boys with undescended testes are at greater risk of infertility, testicular malignancy, hernia, and torsion Hernia- 90% of boys with undescended testis have patent process vaginalis The histopathologic hallmarks of Undescended testis are evident between 1-2 years of age: Decreased numbers of Leydig cells (Earliest abnormality) Degeneration of Sertoli cells Delayed disappearance of gonocytes Delayed appearance of adult dark spermatogonia Failure of primary spermatocytes to develop Reduced total germ cell counts

Random:

Explanation For other Options:- Option: B. Descend to scrotum occurs between 7 and 9 months Option: C. Mechanism of descent is poorly understood but probably involves Mullerian inhibiting substance Option: D. Maternal chorionic gonadotrophin stimulates the growth of the testis and may promote its migration

Extraedge:

UDT is usually an isolated finding, but it may occur as a part of a systemic condition such as Prader-Willi, Eagle-Barrett, or other such complex multisystem syndrome .

questions.text: A 5-year- male child was brought by his parents with complaints of absent testis on the right side of the scrotum. On examination, rugae are normally developed. A firm mass is felt at the right groin. Orr's test is positive. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Retractile testis In retractile testis – the testis is usually developed and can be brought down to the scrotum+, scrotum typically Orr/chair test : The child is asked to sit on a chair, keeping both feet on its seat and knees flexed to the extreme and brought to the chest This puts pressure on the inguinal canal downward and brings retractile testis into the scrotum

Highyeild:

Retractile testis Retractile testes should be differentiated from actual undescended testes This is most easily done with the child relaxed in a warm room Retractile testes are more common than actual undescended testes Retractile testes require no treatment but should be monitored Compared with a true undescended testis, the scrotum in the retractile testis is average as opposed to underdeveloped, and the retractile testis can be gently milked from its position in the inguinal region to the bottom of the scrotum. For retractile testes, a yearly physical examination is recommended because of the 2–50% reported risk of a retractile testis becoming an acquired undescended testis.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. scrotum is underdeveloped, the testis cannot be brought down to the scrotum, and + the chair test is negative. Option: C. occurs due to the rupture of the central scrotal tail of the gubernaculum testis: sites- superficial inguinal pouch, femoral triangle, the base of the penis, and perineum.

questions.text: A 10-year- boy brought by his parents complains of absent right testis since birth. On examination, the scrotum on the right side is underdeveloped, and the testis is not palpable. What is the consequence of not treating undescended testis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above INFERTILITY, MALIGNANCY, TORSION, and HERNIA -are all consequences of undescended testis Infertility- well-recognized effect of male testicular scent Malignancy-cancer risk for adults after cryptorchidism in childhood is 5-10times greater than usual, and seminoma is the commonest Torsion- as a result of developmental abnormality between the testis and mesentery

Highyeild:

Undescended testis Sketchy descent of the testis, also known as cryptorchidism, occurs when one or both testes are arrested at some point in the typical path to the scrotum. Incidence: About 3% of full-term and 30% of premature male infants are born with one or both testes undescended Pathology : (Sites of arrest) Intraabdominal Within the inguinal canal Extracanalicular Ectopic Testes absent from the scrotum after three months of age are unlikely to descend. Histological changes in the testis can be seen from 1 year of age An incompletely descended testis tends to atrophy as puberty approaches Boys with undescended testes are at greater risk of infertility, testicular malignancy, hernia, and torsion Hernia- 90% of boys with undescended testis have patent process vaginalis

Extraedge:

UDT is usually an isolated finding, but it may occur as part of a systemic condition such as Prader-Willi, Eagle-Barrett, or another complex multisystem syndrome .

questions.text: A 5-year- boy is brought by his parents with complaints of absent bilateral testis since birth. On examination scrotum is underdeveloped, and the testis is not palpable. Which of the following is incorrect regarding undescended testis?

options.label: A
options.text: Histological changes in the testis are loss of Sertoli cells, degeneration of Leydig, and decreased spermatogenesis

options.label: B
options.text: Histological changes in the testis can be seen from 1year of age

options.label: C
options.text: An incompletely descended testis tends to atrophy as puberty approaches

options.label: D
options.text: Boys with undescended testis are at greater risk of hernia

questions.correct_answer: A. Histological changes in the testis are loss of Sertoli cells, degeneration of Leydig, and decreased spermatogenesis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Histological changes in the testis are loss of Sertoli cells, degeneration of Leydig, and decreased spermatogenesis Histological changes in the testis are loss of Leydig cells, degeneration of Sertoli, and decreased spermatogenesis

Highyeild:

Undescended testis Sketchy descent of the testis, also known as cryptorchidism, occurs when one or both testes are arrested at some point in the typical path to the scrotum. Incidence: About 3% of full-term and 30% of premature male infants are born with one or both testes undescended Pathology : (Sites of arrest) Intraabdominal Within the inguinal canal Extracanalicular Ectopic Testes that are absent from the scrotum after three months of age are unlikely to descend Histological changes in the testis can be seen from 1 year of age An incompletely descended testis tends to atrophy as puberty approaches Boys with undescended testes are at greater risk of infertility, testicular malignancy, hernia, and torsion Hernia- 90% of boys with undescended testis have patent process vaginalis

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Histological changes in the testis can be seen from 1year of age Option: C. An incompletely descended testis tends to atrophy as puberty approaches Option: D. Boys with undescended testis are at greater risk of hernia

Extraedge:

UDT is usually an isolated finding, but it may occur as part of a systemic condition such as Prader-Willi, Eagle-Barrett, or another complex multisystem syndrome .

questions.text: A 2-year is brought to OPD, complaining of absent right testis since birth. On examination right scrotum is underdeveloped, and the testis is not palpable. Surgeons plan for orchidopexy; which of the following Manoeuvres helps gain length to bring the testis down into the scrotum?

options.label: A
options.text: Patent process should be identified, separated, and ligated

options.label: B
options.text: Covering of the spermatic cord should be divided

options.label: C
options.text: Lateral fibrous just inside the internal ring should be divided

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above ALL THE ABOVE MANOUVRES HELP GAIN LENGTH

Highyeild:

Orchidopexy is usually performed between 6 and 18 months of age to prevent consequences. Three maneuvers help to gain the length required to bring the testis down to the bottom of the scrotum. First, the patent processus vaginalis should be identified, separated, and ligated. Second, the coverings of the spermatic cord (including the cremasteric muscle) should be divided. Third, lateral fibrous bands inside the internal inguinal ring should be divided . Sometimes for higher undescended tesits two-staged procedure is necessary. The testis is mobilized as far as possible and anchored with a suture, and the mobilization is completed six months later. Although these techniques are usually effective, the tiny vas and testicular vessels are vulnerable to injury. The empty hemiscrotum is stretched with a finger passed into it through the inguinal incision to give enough room for the testis, which is placed in a pouch between the dartos muscle and the skin. The alternative approach involves the initial division of the gonadal artery such that the testis become dependent for its blood supply upon the cremaster artery, followed by orchidopexy

Extraedge:

Orchidopexy does not decrease the malignancy risk associated with undescended testes, but it allows for earlier detection.

questions.text: A 20-year- male presented to OPD with complaints of pain in the right scrotum, no history of trauma, fever, or scrotal swelling. On examination no warmth and no scrotal swelling. Tenderness +, on the elevation of the right scrotum, the pain worsens. Ultrasound scrotum shows reduced vascularity to the right testis. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Torsion testis Age + no signs of inflammation+ on the elevation of right scrotum pain worsens + reduced vascularity on ultrasound= torsion

Highyeild:

Testicular torsion is the twisting of the spermatic cord and its contents such that the testicular blood supply becomes compromised Incidence : 10–15% of acute scrotal diseases in children Pathophysiology : High Investment in the tunica vaginalis Inversion of the testis Separation of the epididymis from the body of the testis Factors determining damage to the testis The extent of the twist Duration of the episode Clinical Features : The joint is between 10 and 25 years Sudden severe pain in the groin and lower abdomen Nauseated and Vomit Scrotum - swollen and tender, while the skin is usually not erythematous initially Testis - swollen and tender and seems high within the scrotum Cremasteric Reflex - Lost Differential Diagnosis : Epididymo - Orchitis Idiopathic Scrotal Oedema Management : White doppler Ultrasound Scanning (Confirms the absence of blood supply) Urgent Scrotal Exploration

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Signs of inflammation, fever, and dysuria characterize. epididymal-orchitis . On the scrotum's elevation, the pain reduces. Ultrasound scrotum shows increased vascularity to the testis. Option: C. Hydrocele is usually characterized by swelling; pain is rare and may occur following trauma. It is usually a chronic condition. Option: D. Hematoma occurs following trauma and is characterized by scrotal swelling.

questions.text: A 15year male presented to OPD with complaints of pain in the left scrotum, no history of trauma, fever, or scrotal swelling. On examination no warmth and no scrotal swelling. Tenderness +, on the elevation of the left scrotum, the pain worsens. Cremasteric reflex is lost. Doppler Ultrasound scrotum shows reduced vascularity to the left testis. How will you manage this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bilateral orchidopexy Even in unilateral torsion testis, bilateral orchidopexy is performed if the testis appears viable to prevent torsion from the contralateral side later.

Highyeild:

Testicular torsion is the twisting of the spermatic cord and its contents such that the testicular blood supply becomes compromised Incidence : 10–15% of acute scrotal diseases in children Pathophysiology : High Investment in the tunica vaginalis Inversion of the testis Separation of the epididymis from the body of the testis Factors determining damage to the testis The extent of the twist Duration of the episode Clinical Features : The joint is between 10 and 25 years Sudden severe pain in the groin and lower abdomen Nauseated and Vomit Scrotum - swollen and tender, while the skin is usually not erythematous initially Testis - swollen and tender and seems high within the scrotum Cremasteric Reflex - Lost Differential Diagnosis : Epididymo - Orchitis Idiopathic Scrotal Oedema Management : White doppler Ultrasound Scanning (Confirms the absence of blood supply) Urgent Scrotal Exploration

Extraedge:

Orchidopexy does not decrease the malignancy risk associated with undescended testes, but it allows for earlier detection.

questions.text: A 30-year- male presented with complaints of right scrotal pain for two days. A history of dysuria is present. No history of fever or trauma. On examination warmth +, tenderness+, scrotum enlargement+. Ultrasound scrotum shows increased vascularity right testis. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Epididymo-orchitis Signs of inflammation, fever, and dysuria characterize Epididymo-orchitis. The pain reduces on the elevation of the scrotum. Ultrasound scrotum shows increased vascularity to the testis.

Highyeild:

Epididymo-Orchitis Inflammation confined to the epididymis is epididymitis; if this inflammation, usually due to infection, involves the testis, it is called epididymal-orchitis Acute : In young men usually arises secondary to a sexually transmitted genital infection(Most commonly due to chlamydia trachomatis ) In older men usually occurs secondary to urinary infection It may be a complication of catheterization or instrumentation of the urinary tract Investigation: Urethral swab, a Urine specimen for culture, nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) of either a urine specimen or a urethral swab, and scrotal ultrasound They may need aggressive treatment with parenteral antibiotics Chronic : Usually follows the failure of resolution of an acute episode of epididymitis Intermittent bouts of discomfort and the epididymis feels thickened and tender Treatment : Antibiotics (usually quinolones or doxycycline) and anti-infammatory agents for 4–6 weeks Epididymectomy or orchidectomy

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Age + no signs of inflammation+ on the elevation of right scrotum pain worsens + reduced vascularity on ultrasound= torsion. Option: C. Hydrocele is usually characterized by swelling; pain is rare and may occur following trauma. It is usually a chronic condition. Signs of inflammation are absent. Option: D. Hernia is an inguinoscrotal swelling characterized by cough impulse; no signs of inflammation are present, and ultrasound shows a defect.

questions.text: A 35-year- male presented complaints of left scrotal pain for two days. h/o dysuria is present. A history of fever is present, but no history of trauma. On examination warmth +, tenderness+, scrotum enlargement+. Ultrasound scrotum shows increased vascularity right testis. How will you manage this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Antibiotics It is a case of epididymal orchitis treated with antibiotics and scrotal support.

Highyeild:

Epididymo-Orchitis Inflammation confined to the epididymis is epididymitis; if this inflammation, usually due to infection, involves the testis, it is called epididymal-orchitis Acute : In young men usually arises secondary to a sexually transmitted genital infection(Most commonly due to chlamydia trachomatis ) In older men usually occurs secondary to urinary infection It may be a complication of catheterization or instrumentation of the urinary tract Investigation: Urethral swab, a Urine specimen for culture, nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) of either a urine specimen or a urethral swab, and scrotal ultrasound They may need aggressive treatment with parenteral antibiotics Chronic : Usually follows the failure of resolution of an acute episode of epididymitis Intermittent bouts of discomfort and the epididymis feels thickened and tender Treatment : Antibiotics (usually quinolones or doxycycline) and anti-infammatory agents for 4–6 weeks Epididymectomy or orchidectomy

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Scrotal exploration is needed in a young patient in whom the clinical finding and radiological finding do not co-relate Option: C. If suppuration occurs, incision and drainage are indicated Option: D. Orchidectomy is not stated in epididymal-orchitis unless the testis becomes gangrenous

questions.text: A 60year diabetic patient presents with complaints of swelling and pain right scrotum and fever for 1day. On examination, the right scrotum is enlarged and inflamed, scrotal skin necrosis+, crepitus is present, and foul-smelling discharge is present. leucocytes- 20,000, blood urea- 50mg/dl, serum creatinine-2mg/dl. What is the treatment of choice for this patient

options.label: D
options.text: Initially treat the patient conservatively. If it worsens, proceed to debridement

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Debridement It is a case of Fournier’s gangrene. The polymicrobial organism causes it. Fulminating inflammation of subcutaneous tissue, which results in obliterative arteritis of arterioles to scrotal skin leading to gangrene It is a surgical emergency -wide surgical excision of dead &infected tissue is essential

Highyeild:

Fournier’s gangrene is an uncommon and nasty condition characterized by a polymicrobial infection of the soft tissues of the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region. It is a form of necrotizing fasciitis Clinical Features : The hallmark of Fournier’s gangrene is intense pain and tenderness in the genitalia. Prodromal symptoms of fever and lethargy for 2–7 days; Intense genital pain is usually associated with edema of the overlying skin; pruritus may be present; Increasing genital pain with progressive erythema of the overlying skin; The dusky appearance of the overlying skin, subcutaneous crepitation; Obvious gangrene of part of the genitalia; purulent discharge from wounds Treatment : Initial management involves intravenous fuid resuscitation and broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics. Urgent wide surgical excision of the dead and infected tissue is essential, and the extent of the internal necrosis is typically much greater than the external appearances suggest, with extensive debridement often necessary

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Initial management involves fluid resuscitation and broad-spectrum antibiotics Option: C. Scrotal support is not a treatment for necrotizing fasciitis. It’s a supportive treatment for epididymal-orchitis Option: D. It is a rapidly spreading infection. Hence this protocol of management would not suffice, and part of the scrotal is already gangrenous.

questions.text: A 25year male presented to the OPD with complaints of pain left scrotum for one week – dragging type, which worsens at the end of the day. On examination of the patient in supine, the scrotum, and testis are normal. In an erect position, the hernial orifices are free; on palpating scrotum could be felt like a bag of worms, and a cough impulse is present. What could be the probable diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Varicocele Varicocele is a varicose dilatation of veins draining the testis. C/F- Asymptomatic, dragging discomfort that worsens on standing at the end of the day On palpation, varicose plexus feels like a bag of worm appearance Rarely need treatment. It is more common on the left side.

Highyeild:

Varicocele A varicocele is an abnormal dilatation and enlargement of the scrotal venous plexus draining the testis. Incidence: Varicoceles are common, affecting 10–20% of adult males. About 90% are left-sided, reflecting the proximal venous anatomy. Pathophysiology : (Theories) The absence or failure of the antireflux valve is usually located where the testicular vein joins the left renal vein or the inferior vena cava on the right. This causes reflux and retrograde flow in the testicular vein. The ‘nutcracker’ effect occurs when the left testicular vein gets trapped between the superior mesenteric artery and the aorta. This causes venous compression and testicular vein obstruction. Angulation at the junction of the left testicular and renal veins. Clinical Features: Mostly asymptomatic If symptomatic, a dragging discomfort on standing may occur When examined in the erect position, the scrotum on the affected side often hangs lower than normal On palpation, with the patient standing, the varicose plexus feels like a bag of worms Clinical Classification: Subclinical: not palpable or visible at rest or during a Valsalva maneuver but can be shown by special tests (Doppler ultrasound studies); Grade 1: detectable during Valsalva maneuver, but not otherwise; Grade 2: noticeable at rest, but not visible; Grade 3: visible and tangible at rest. Diagnosis: Ultrasound Treatment: Varicocele Repair

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Inguinal hernia is an abnormal protrusion of the whole or part of the viscus through the wall that contains it. It is reducible; cough impulse is present. Option: B. It is the dilatation of the saphenous vein at its junction with a femoral vein in the groin, cough impulse+ Option: D. It is an inflammation confined to the epididymis and testis. There are no signs of inflammation; in this case,

Extraedge:

Varicocele is an anatomical finding in the causative factors of fertility. Abnormal semen parameters may indicate a wide range of disorders that may cause reduced sperm numbers, motility, or morphology, including varicocele.

questions.text: A 30-year- male presented to the OPD with complaints of pain left scrotum for three months – dragging type, which worsens at the end of the day. On examination of the patient in supine, the scrotum and testis are normal. In the erect position, the hernial orifices are free; palpating the scrotum could be felt like a bag of worms, and a cough impulse is present. The patient is married and the father of two children. Ultrasound shows f/s/o varicocele; ultrasound abdomen is normal. What is the first-line varicocele treatment for symptomatic patients?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Embolization When discomfort is present, percutaneous embolization of gonadal veins is usually the first-line intervention. 20% recur

Highyeild:

Varicocele A varicocele is an abnormal dilatation and enlargement of the scrotal venous plexus draining the testis Incidence: Varicoceles are common, affecting 10–20% of adult males. About 90% are left-sided, reflecting the proximal venous anatomy. Pathophysiology : (Theories) The absence or failure of the antireflux valve is usually located where the testicular vein joins the left renal or inferior vein vena cava on the right. This causes reflux and retrograde flow in the testicular vein. The ‘nutcracker’ effect occurs when the left testicular vein gets trapped between the superior mesenteric artery and the aorta. This causes venous compression and testicular vein obstruction. Angulation at the junction of the left testicular vein and the left renal vein. Clinical Features: Mostly asymptomatic If symptomatic, a dragging discomfort on standing may occur When examined in the erect position, the scrotum on the affected side often hangs lower than normal On palpation, with the patient standing, the varicose plexus feels like a bag of worms Clinical Classification: Subclinical: not palpable or visible at rest or during a Valsalva manoeuvre, but can be shown by special tests (Doppler ultrasound studies); Grade 1: palpable during Valsalva manoeuvre, but not otherwise; Grade 2: palpable at rest, but not visible; Grade 3: visible and palpable at rest. Diagnosis: Ultrasound Treatment: Varicocele Repair

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. It is indicated in asymptomatic patients Option: C. If embolisation is not possible or if varicocele recurs, then surgical ligation of the testicular vein is the appropriate treatment Option: D. Orchidectomy has no role in varicocele

Extraedge:

Varicocele is an anatomical finding in the causative factors of fertility. Abnormal semen parameters may indicate a wide range of disorders that may cause reduced sperm numbers, motility, or morphology, including varicocele

questions.text: A 30year came to the hospital with complaints of swelling right testis for two months. On examination of the testis, it is enlarged and hard in consistency. Physical examination shows a long & slender face with a prominent lower jaw, long hands and legs, gynecomastia, and micro-penis. Which of the following is a risk factor for the testicular tumour?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Klinefelter syndrome Klinefelter syndrome is a risk factor for testicular tumour

Highyeild:

Epidemiological risk factors include: Cryptorchidism, Male factor infertility (including Klinefelter syndrome), Familial history of testicular tumours among first-grade relatives The presence of a contralateral tumour or GCNIS.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Downs syndrome is trisomy 21, has an increased risk of developing AML OR ALL Option: C. Turner syndrome has an increased risk of developing meningioma, bladder cancer, and melanoma. Option: D. Poland syndrome is underdeveloped chest muscle and short webbed fingers on one side of the body

questions.text: A 35-year- male presented to the OPD with complaints of a right testicular lump and pain for Three months. On examination, there is no warmth or tenderness, and the right testis is enlarged and consistently hard. Necessary investigations were done and diagnosed as testicular tumours. Which of the following is the most common testicular malignancy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Seminoma Testicular tumours are classified into germ and non–germ cells. 95% of testicular tumours are germ cell tumours, and seminoma constitutes more than 50% of all testis cancer

Highyeild:

A seminoma typically has a cut surface that is homogeneous and pinkish cream in colour. It appears to compress neighbouring testicular tissue Incidence: Seminoma accounts for 50% of all testicular germinal cell tumours. Features : It consists of oval cells with clear cytoplasm and large, rounded nuclei with prominent acidophilic nucleoli. They seldom occur in childhood, in young adults or in patients over 70. A fine fibrous stroma separates sheets of cells resembling spermatocytes. Active lymphocytic infiltration of the tumour suggests a good host response and a better prognosis. Metastasis: Seminomas metastasise mainly via the lymphatics, and haematogenous spread is uncommon. The lymphatic drainage of the testes is to the para-aortic lymph nodes near the origin of the gonadal vessels. The contralateral para-aortic lymph nodes are sometimes involved in tumour spread, but the inguinal lymph nodes are affected only if the scrotal skin is involved. Investigation : Ultrasound is the first-line investigation Management: Seminoma . About 15% of patients with clinical stage I (CSI) seminoma have subclinical metastatic disease, usually in the retroperitoneum, and will relapse after orchidectomy alone. Surveillance . Recurrence rates of 6% have been described in patients with low-risk features, including tumour size <4 cm and no stromal rete testis invasion with cancer-specific survival rate reported with surveillance at >95% Adjuvant chemotherapy . Adjuvant radiotherapy . Seminomas are radiosensitive.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Lymphoma is rare and constitutes 3-7% Option: C. Yolk sac tumour is a germ cell tumour Option: D. Interstitial tumours constitute 1-2%

Extraedge:

The halflife of β-human chorionic gonadotropin is 24 to 36 hours, and the half-life of α-fetoprotein is 5 to 7 days; these levels should normalise in the absence of metastatic disease

questions.text: A 40-year- male presented to the OPD with complaints of a testicular lump for six months. Necessary investigations were done, AFP- 10ng/ml, beta HCG- 1.5m IU/L, CT Abdomen shows nodal involvement below the diaphragm. attending surgeon suspected it to be a testicular tumour and with the consent of the Patient, an orchidectomy was done for the same and discharged. After one week, the patient came for review with an HPE report suggesting a yolk sac tumour. what is the next management step?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

BEP chemotherapy For stage II-IV Seminoma and NSGCT, BEP chemotherapy is the mainstay of treatment Chemotherapy for extragonadal GCT: Combination of Bleomycin + Etoposide + Cisplatin (BEP)

Highyeild:

Yolk sac tumour: Usually present with a loose stroma and a component similar to embryonal carcinoma, sometimes with liver and intestinal tissue differentiation. It appears as a single tumour type in children and part of a mixed tumour in adults. They produce alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), which can be measured in serum Management of NSGCT Up to 50% of patients with NSGCT with CSI disease have subclinical metastases and will relapse during surveillance. Surveillance : 14–48% of CSI-NSGCT patients undergoing surveillance have a recurrence within two years of orchidectomy. Careful surveillance can be an option for compliant, risk-stratified (based on the presence of lymphovascular invasion) patients who are well-informed about the expected recurrence rate and the salvage treatment. Adjuvant chemotherapy : One cycle of bleomycin–etoposide– cisplatin (BEP) is now the recommended strategy with recurrence rates of around 3%. The very long-term side effects, particularly cardiovascular, remain to be ascertained. Retroperitoneal lymph node dissection (RPLND) : The role of this surgery has now decreased with 2-year recurrence-free survival with adjuvant BEP × 1 versus RPLND favoring chemotherapy with a recurrence-free survival of 99.5% versus 91%.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. NSGCT are not radiosensitive Option: D. It is a chemotherapy regimen for CA breast

questions.text: Clinical scenario having scrotum with a bag of worms
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Varicocele When examined in the erect position, the scrotum on the affected side hangs lower than usual; on palpation, with the patient standing, the varicose plexus feels like a bag of worms.

Highyeild:

Varicocele A varicocele is an abnormal dilatation and enlargement of the scrotal venous plexus draining the testis Incidence: Varicoceles are common, affecting 10–20% of adult males. This causes venous compression and testicular vein obstruction. Angulation at the junction of the left testicular vein and the left renal vein. Clinical Features: Mostly asymptomatic If symptomatic, a dragging discomfort on standing may occur When examined in the erect position, the scrotum on the affected side often hangs lower than normal On palpation, with the patient standing, the varicose plexus feels like a bag of worms Clinical Classification: Subclinical: not palpable or visible at rest or during a Valsalva maneuver, but can be shown by special tests (Doppler ultrasound studies); Grade 1: palpable during Valsalva maneuver, but not otherwise; Grade 2: palpable at rest, but not visible; Grade 3: visible and palpable at rest. Diagnosis: Ultrasound Treatment: Varicocele Repair

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Inguinal hernia is an abnormal protrusion of the whole or part of the viscus through the wall that contains it. It is reducible; cough impulse is present. Option: B. It is the dilatation of the saphenous vein at its junction with a femoral vein in the groin, cough impulse+ Option: D. It is an inflammation confined to the epididymis and testis. There are no signs of inflammation; in this case,

Extraedge:

questions.text: A 35- year- old male presented with swelling above the upper pole of the testis on the right side. It is softer and lax and contains barley water-like fluid in its cysts. Which is the probable diagnosis ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Spermatocele A spermatocele typically lies in the epididymal head above and behind the upper pole of the testis. It is usually softer and laxer than other cystic lesions in the scrotum but, like them, it transilluminates

Highyeild:

Spermatocoele : This is a unilocular retention cyst derived from some portion of the sperm-conducting mechanism of the epididymis. Presentation: A spermatocele typically lies in the epididymal head above and behind the upper pole of the testis. It is usually softer and laxer than other cystic lesions in the scrotum but, like them, it transilluminates. The fluid contains spermatozoa and resembles barley water in appearance. Spermatocoeles are usually small and unobtrusive. Treatment : Small spermatoceles can be ignored. Larger ones should be excised.

questions.text: The ideal time to do Orchidopexy is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

between 6 and 18 months Orchidopexy is usually performed between 6 and 18 months of age to prevent the consequences described earlier. The testis and spermatic cord are mobilized, and the testis is repositioned in the scrotum. The operation is performed through a short incision over the deep inguinal ring. The inguinal canal is exposed by division of the external oblique aponeurosis in the direction of its fibers.

Highyeild:

Orchidopexy is usually performed between 6 and 18 months of age to prevent consequences. Three maneuvers help to gain the length required to bring the testis down to the bottom of the scrotum. First, the patent processus vaginalis should be identified, separated, and ligated. Second, the coverings of the spermatic cord (including the cremasteric muscle) should be divided Third, lateral fibrous bands just inside the internal inguinal ring should be divided . Sometimes, for higher undescended tests two-staged procedure is necessary. The testis is mobilized as far as possible and anchored with a suture, and the mobilization is completed six months later. Although these techniques are usually effective, the tiny vas and testicular vessels are vulnerable to injury. The empty hemiscrotum is stretched with a finger passed into it through the inguinal incision to give enough room for the testis, which is placed in a pouch constructed between the dartos muscle and the skin The alternative approach involves the initial division of the gonadal artery such that the testis become dependent for its blood supply upon the cremaster artery, followed by orchidopexy

Extraedge:

Orchidopexy does not decrease the malignancy risk associated with undescended testes, but it allows for earlier detection

questions.text: Lord's plication is done for
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hydrocele Lord’s operation is suitable when the sac is reasonably thin-walled. There is minimal dissection, and the risk of haematoma is reduced.

Highyeild:

Hydrocele: A hydrocele is an abnormal collection of serous fuid in a part of the processus vaginalis, usually the tunica vaginalis around the testis and occasionally along the spermatic cord Types: Communicating Non- Communicating Mixed(Distal end closes correctly, but the mid-portion remains patent) Diagnosis: Hydroceles surround the testis and transilluminate brightly Ultrasound examination is valuable, especially when the testis and epididymis are impalpable Treatment: Congenital hydroceles are treated by herniotomy if they do not resolve spontaneously. Small acquired hydroceles do not need treatment . Surgical treatment is indicated if they are sizeable and bothersome for the patient. Established acquired hydroceles often have thick walls. There are three main surgical techniques for hydroceles; Plication : Lord’s operation is suitable when the sac is reasonably thin-walled. There is minimal dissection, and the risk of haematoma is reduced. Eversion : The sac is opened and everted behind the testis, with the placement of the testis in a pouch prepared by dissection in the fascial planes of the scrotum (Jaboulay’s procedure) Excision : Unless great care is taken to stop bleeding after excision of the wall, haemorrhage from the cut edge is liable to cause a large scrotal haematoma. This approach is not recommended. Aspiration of the hydrocoele fluid is simple, but the fluid always reaccumulates within a week or so. It may suit men unfit for scrotal surgery, although hydrocoele surgery can be undertaken under local anaesthetic. Aspiration can result in bleeding into the hydrocoele sac and haematocoele formation. Injection of a sclerosant, such as a tetracycline, is effective but painful.

Extraedge:

Hydrocele may also be associated with other conditions, such as epididymitis, testicular torsion, and testicular appendage torsion. In these instances, ultrasound examination may be helpful to determine the diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following is not a germ cell tumour
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Leydig cell tumour Tumours of the testis are classified according to their predominant cellular type: Germ cell tumours (90–95%) (these include seminoma, embryonal cell carcinoma, yolk sac tumour, teratoma, and choriocarcinoma); Interstitial tumours (1–2%) (these include Leydig cell tumours); Lymphoma (3–7%); Other tumours (1–2%).

Highyeild:

Leydig cell tumour Leydig cell tumours are the most common type of sex cord–stromal tumours, constituting 1–3% of adult testicular tumours 3% of testicular tumours in infants and children. These tumours occur in about 8% of patients with Klinefelter’s syndrome. They are well delineated on histology and usually up to 5 cm in diameter. They are solid, yellow to tan in color, with haemorrhage and necrosis in 30% of cases. Most of these tumours are benign. Malignant transformation occurs in 10% and is related to increased size (>5 cm), cellular atypia, cell proliferation, necrosis, vessel invasion, and DNA aneuploidy.

questions.text: Testicular tumor extending into epididymis is staged as
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Stage I While TNM staging is the most widely used system for staging testicular cancer, the older staging system of Stages I-IV is still considered valuable in determining the treatment options. The stages are Stage I: Tumour is confined to the testis and epididymis. Stage II: Nodal disease is present but is confined to nodes below the diaphragm. Stage III: Nodes are present above the diaphragm. Stage IV: Nonlymphatic metastatic disease (typically within the lungs).

Extraedge:

The halflife of β-human chorionic gonadotropin is 24 to 36 hours, and the half-life of α-fetoprotein is 5 to 7 days; these levels should normalize in the absence of metastatic disease

questions.text: Treatment of Non-Seminomatous Germ Cell tumour is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chemotherapy NSGCTs are not radiosensitive but susceptible to combination chemotherapy with bleomycin, etoposide, and cis-platinum (so-called BEP chemotherapy).

Highyeild:

Testis tumor staging and treatment Tumour markers (AFP, HCG, and LDH) help to make the diagnosis and to follow the response to treatment CT scanning of chest, abdomen, and pelvis is central to the staging of testicular tumors Testicular tumors are susceptible to platinum-based chemotherapy Prognosis is excellent when the patient is treated with combination chemotherapy in a cancer center Management of NSGCT Up to 50% of patients with NSGCT with CSI disease have subclinical metastases and will relapse during surveillance. Surveillance : 14–48% of CSI-NSGCT patients undergoing surveillance have a recurrence within two years of orchidectomy. Careful surveillance can be an option for compliant, risk-stratified (based on the presence of lymphovascular invasion) patients who are well-informed about the expected recurrence rate and the salvage treatment. Adjuvant chemotherapy : One cycle of bleomycin–etoposide– cisplatin (BEP) is now the recommended strategy with recurrence rates of around 3%. The very long-term side effects, particularly cardiovascular, remain to be ascertained. Retroperitoneal lymph node dissection (RPLND) : The role of this surgery has now decreased with 2-year recurrence-free survival with adjuvant BEP × 1 versus RPLND favoring chemotherapy with a recurrence-free survival of 99.5% versus 91%.

Extraedge:

The halflife of β-human chorionic gonadotropin is 24 to 36 hours, and the half-life of α-fetoprotein is 5 to 7 days; these levels should normalize in the absence of metastatic disease
